facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 124 of 1951 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 124 of 1951.

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by His Majesty in Council on 30th October 1945.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by His Majesty in Council, dated the 30th October, 1945, from the Judgment and Decree, dated the 12th July, 1944, of the High Court of Judicature at Lahore in Civil Regular Second Appeal No. 450 of 1942

facts.text: High Court of Judicature at Lahore passed Judgment and Decree on 12th July 1944 in Civil Regular Second Appeal No. 450 of 1942.

anchor.surface_text: from the Judgment and Decree, dated the 12th July, 1944, of the High Court of Judicature at Lahore in Civil Regular Second Appeal No. 450 of 1942, against the Judgment and Decree, dated the 14th January, 1942, of the Court of the District Judge, Gurdaspur

facts.text: District Judge Gurdaspur passed Judgment and Decree on 14th January 1942 in Appeal No. 91 of 1941.

anchor.surface_text: against the Judgment and Decree, dated the 14th January, 1942, of the Court of the District Judge, Gurdaspur, in Appeal No. 91 of 1941, arising from the Judgment and Decree, dated 31st July, 1941, of the Court of Senior Subordinate Judge, Gurdaspur, in Suit No. 80 of 1940.

facts.text: Senior Subordinate Judge Gurdaspur passed Judgment and Decree on 31st July 1941 in Suit No. 80 of 1940, dismissing the appellants' suit.

anchor.surface_text: arising from the Judgment and Decree, dated 31st July, 1941, of the Court of Senior Subordinate Judge, Gurdaspur, in Suit No. 80 of 1940. S. Vohra and Harbans Singh for the appellants. Achhru Ram  J. B. Dadachanji and R. N. Sachthey, with him  for respondents. 1954. April 1.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 1, 1954 by GHULAM HASAN J.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. April 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GHULAM HASAN J.-This is an appeal by special leave granted by the Privy Council against the judgment and decree dated July 12, 1944, of a Division Bench of the High Court at Lahore passed in second appeal confirming the dismissal of the appellants suit concurrently by the trial Court and the Court of the District Judge, Gurdaspur.

facts.text: Two appellants are first cousins of respondent Harnam Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The two appellants are admittedly the first cousins of the respondent, Harnam Singh, and belong to village Gillanwali, Tahsil Batala, District Gurdaspur.

facts.text: Appellants and Harnam Singh belong to village Gillanwali, Tahsil Batala, District Gurdaspur.

anchor.surface_text: The two appellants are admittedly the first cousins of the respondent, Harnam Singh, and belong to village Gillanwali, Tahsil Batala, District Gurdaspur. Gurmej Singh, respondent No. 2, is a collateral of Harnam Singh in the 8th degree.

facts.text: Gurmej Singh (respondent No. 2) is a collateral of Harnam Singh in the 8th degree.

anchor.surface_text: Gurmej Singh, respondent No. 2, is a collateral of Harnam Singh in the 8th degree. The appellants sued for a declaration that the deed of adoption executed by Harnam Singh on July 30, 1940, adopting Gurmej Singh was invalid and could not affect the reversionary rights of the appellants after the death of Harnam Singh.

facts.text: Harnam Singh executed deed of adoption on July 30, 1940, adopting Gurmej Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants sued for a declaration that the deed of adoption executed by Harnam Singh on July 30, 1940, adopting Gurmej Singh was invalid and could not affect the reversionary rights of the appellants after the death of Harnam Singh.

facts.text: Appellants sued for declaration that the adoption deed was invalid and would not affect their reversionary rights after Harnam Singh's death.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants sued for a declaration that the deed of adoption executed by Harnam Singh on July 30, 1940, adopting Gurmej Singh was invalid and could not affect the reversionary rights of the appellants after the death of Harnam Singh. The appellants case was that under the Customary Law of Gurdaspur District applicable to the Gill Jats ,of village Gillanwali, Harnam Singh could only adopt a near collateral and Gurmej Singh being a distant collateral his adoption was invalid.

facts.text: Appellants claimed under Customary Law of Gurdaspur District for Gill Jats of Gillanwali, adoption only of near collaterals.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case was that under the Customary Law of Gurdaspur District applicable to the Gill Jats ,of village Gillanwali, Harnam Singh could only adopt a near collateral and Gurmej Singh being a distant collateral his adoption was invalid. The defence was a denial of the plaintiffs claim.

facts.text: Defence denied plaintiffs' claim.

anchor.surface_text: The defence was a denial of the plaintiffs claim. Both the trial Judge and the District Judge on appeal held that the factum and the validity of the adoption were fully established.

facts.text: Trial Judge and District Judge held factum and validity of adoption established.

anchor.surface_text: Both the trial Judge and the District Judge on appeal held that the factum and the validity of the adoption were fully established. In second appeal Trevor Harries C. J. and Mahajan J.  as he then was  held that there was sufficient evidence of the factum of adoption as furnished by the deed and the subsequent conduct of Harnam Singh.

facts.text: High Court (Trevor Harries C.J. and Mahajan J.) held sufficient evidence of factum of adoption from deed and Harnam Singh's conduct.

anchor.surface_text: In second appeal Trevor Harries C. J. and Mahajan J.  as he then was  held that there was sufficient evidence of the factum of adoption as furnished by the deed and the subsequent conduct of Harnam Singh. They held that all that was necessary under the custom to constitute an adoption was the expression of a clear intention on the part of the adoptive father to adopt the boy concerned as his son and this intention was clearly manifested here by the execution and registration of the deed of adoption coupled with the public declarations and treatment as adopted son.

facts.text: High Court held Question 9 of Riwaj-i-am 1913 not mandatory for adoption of near collaterals only.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the legal validity of the adoption the High Court found that the answer to Question 9 of the Riwaj-i-am of Gurdaspur District of the year 1913 laying down that the adoption of near collaterals only was recognised was not mandatory.

facts.text: Deed of adoption Exhibit D.1 recites Harnam Singh had no male issue to perform kirya karam.

anchor.surface_text: The deed of adoption, Exhibit D. 1, recites that Harnam Singh had no male issue who could perform his kiry a karam ceremony after his death, that Gurmej Singh had been brought up while he was an infant by his wife and that he had adopted him according to the prevailing custom.

facts.text: Deed recites Gurmej Singh brought up by Harnam Singh's wife as infant.

anchor.surface_text: that Gurmej Singh had been brought up while he was an infant by his wife and that he had adopted him according to the prevailing custom. The recital continues that since the adoption he had been treating and calling Gurmej Singh as his adopted son.

facts.text: Deed states Harnam Singh treated Gurmej as adopted son since adoption, well-known in village.

anchor.surface_text: The recital continues that since the adoption he had been treating and calling Gurmej Singh as his adopted son. This fact was well,-known in the village and the adoptee was en- joying all rights of a son. He had executed a formal document in his favour in order to put an end to any dispute which might be raised about his adoption.

facts.text: Supreme Court satisfied ample evidence for factum of adoption.

anchor.surface_text: As adopted son he made him the owner of all of his property. We are satisfied that there is ample evidence to sustain the finding on the factum of adoption.

facts.text: Gurmej Singh is collateral of Harnam Singh in 8th degree.

anchor.surface_text: The main question which falls to be considered is whether under the terms of the Riwaj-i-am applicable to the parties, Gurmej Singh being a collateral of Harnam Singh in the 8th degree could be validly adopted.

facts.text: Custom based on Question 9 of Riwaj-i-am of Gurdaspur District.

anchor.surface_text: The custom in question is founded on Question 9 and its answer the Customary Law of the Gurdaspur District. They are as follows- Question 9. Is there any rule by which it is required that the person adopted should be related to the person adopting ?

facts.text: Appellants contended 'near collaterals only' means up to third degree, mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: It is contended for the appellants that the expression near collaterals only must be construed to mean a collateral up to the third degree and does not cover the case of a remote collateral in the 8th degree.

facts.text: Supreme Court held expression 'near collaterals' ambiguous, not mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: The expression near collaterals is not defined by the custom. The relevant answer which we have underlined above gives no indication as to the precise import of the words near collaterals.

facts.text: Supreme Court held custom in Riwaj-i-am directory, not mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: We are also of opinion that the language used amounts to no more than an expression of a wish on the part of the narrators of the custom and is not mandatory.

issues.text: whether the factum of adoption is established

anchor.surface_text: The first question regarding the factum of adoption need not detain us long. The deed of adoption, Exhibit D. 1, recites that Harnam Singh had no male issue who could perform his kiry a karam ceremony after his death, that Gurmej Singh had been brought up while he was an infant by his wife and that he had adopted him according to the prevailing custom.

issues.text: whether under the terms of the Riwaj-i-am applicable to the parties, Gurmej Singh being a collateral of Harnam Singh in the 8th degree could be validly adopted

anchor.surface_text: The main question which falls to be considered is whether under the terms of the Riwaj-i-am applicable to the parties, Gurmej Singh being a collateral of Harnam Singh in the 8th degree could be validly adopted. The custom in question is founded on Question 9 and its answer the Customary Law of the Gurdaspur District.

issues.text: whether the adoption is invalid because under the Customary Law of Gurdaspur District applicable to the Gill Jats of village Gillanwali, Harnam Singh could only adopt a near collateral and Gurmej Singh being a distant collateral

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case was that under the Customary Law of Gurdaspur District applicable to the Gill Jats ,of village Gillanwali, Harnam Singh could only adopt a near collateral and Gurmej Singh being a distant collateral his adoption was invalid. The defence was a denial of the plaintiffs claim.

issues.text: whether the custom recorded in the Riwaj-i-am limiting adoption to near collaterals only is proved by clear and unequivocal language as it is in derogation of the general custom and is mandatory

anchor.surface_text: The expression near collaterals is not defined by the custom. The relevant answer which we have underlined above gives no indication as to the precise import of the words near collaterals. The custom recorded in the Riwaj-i-am is in derogation of the general custom and those who set up such a custom must prove it by clear and unequivocal language. The language is on the face of it ambiguous and we can see no warrant for limiting the expression to signify collateral relationship only up to a certain degree and no further. We are also of opinion that the language used amounts to no more than an expression of a wish on the part of the narrators of the custom and is not mandatory.

issues.text: whether the principle of factum valet applies to directory declarations in the Riwaj-i-am such that the adoption is valid despite non-compliance with directory preferences

arguments.claim: Answer to Question 9 of Riwaj-i-am 1913 that adoption of near collaterals only recognised is not mandatory

anchor.surface_text: Upon the legal validity of the adoption the High Court found that the answer to Question 9 of the Riwaj-i-am of Gurdaspur District of the year 1913 laying down that the adoption of near collaterals only was recognised was not mandatory. The High Court relied in support of their conclusion on a decision of Tek Chand J. in Jowala v. Diwan Singh  1  and the Privy Council decision in Basant Singh v. Brij Raj Saran Singh  2 .

arguments.claim: Ample evidence sustains finding on factum of adoption from deed recitals and conduct

anchor.surface_text: The first question regarding the factum of adoption need not detain us long. The deed of adoption, Exhibit D. 1, recites that Harnam Singh had no male issue who could perform his kiry a karam ceremony after his death, that Gurmej Singh had been brought up while he was an infant by his wife and that he had adopted him according to the prevailing custom. The recital continues that since the adoption he had been treating and calling Gurmej Singh as his adopted son.

arguments.claim: Expression 'near collaterals only' means collateral up to third degree, does not cover remote 8th degree; restriction mandatory and cannot be ignored

anchor.surface_text: It is contended for the appellants that the expression near collaterals only must be construed to mean a collateral up to the third degree and does not cover the case of a remote collateral in the 8th degree. The restriction as regards the degree of relationship of the adoptee, it is urged, is mandatory and cannot be ignored.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: a relation in preference to a stranger, are only directory therefore, the adoption of an only son, or a stranger in preference to a relation, if compa

arguments.court_reasoning: Expression not defined, ambiguous, no indication of precise import or limit to certain degree

arguments.claim: Custom in Riwaj-i-am in derogation of general custom must be proved by clear and unequivocal language; here language ambiguous

anchor.surface_text: The expression near collaterals is not defined by the custom. The relevant answer which we have underlined above gives no indication as to the precise import of the words near collaterals. The custom recorded in the Riwaj-i-am is in derogation of the general custom and those who set up such a custom must prove it by clear and unequivocal language.

arguments.claim: Language in Riwaj-i-am amounts to expression of wish by narrators, not mandatory; ambiguous words show no mandatory intent; right of selection with adopter detracts from mandatory nature

anchor.surface_text: We are also of opinion that the language used amounts to no more than an expression of a wish on the part of the narrators of the custom and is not mandatory. If the intention was to give it a mandatory force, the Riwaj-i-am would have avoided the use of ambiguous words which are susceptible of a conflicting interpretation.

arguments.claim: Punjab customary adoption is secular appointment of heir for agricultural pursuits with great latitude in selection of kinsman regardless of degree, unlike religious Hindu adoption

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the basic idea underlying a customary adoption prevalent in the Punjab is the appointment of an heir to the adopter with a view to associate him in his agricultural pursuits and family affairs. The object is to confer a personal benefit upon a kinsman from the secular point of view unlike the adoption under the Hindu Law where the primary consideration in the mind of the adopter if a male is to derive spiritual benefit

arguments.claim: Texts preferring relations or prohibiting only son are directory under Hindu law; factum valet applies to directory texts making act valid

anchor.surface_text: unlike the adoption under the Hindu Law where the primary consideration in the mind of the adopter if a male is to derive spiritual benefit and if a female, to confer such benefit upon her husband. That is why no emphasis is laid on any ceremonies and great latitude is allowed to the adopter in the matter of selection. Mulla in his well-known work on Hindu Law says It has similarly been held that the texts which prohibit the adoption of an only son, and those which enjoin the adoption of a relation in preference to a stranger, are only directory therefore,

arguments.claim: Declarations in Riwaj-i-am are directory like above texts; factum valet applies; no reason to treat differently

Cited cases show peremptory language in Riwaj-i-am held directory: Jiwan Singh (9th degree valid), Sant Singh (distant preferred), Chanan Singh (no brotherhood ok), Jowala (4th degree ok), Basant Singh (different gotra ok)
No case where declarations governing customary adoptions held mandatory; conceded by counsel
Mandatory or directory depends on custom's essential characteristic; Punjab adoption secular so rules on ceremonies and preferences directory

anchor.surface_text: As adopted son he made him the owner of all of his property. We are satisfied that there is ample evidence to sustain the finding on the factum of adoption.

holdings.text: under the terms of the Riwaj-i-am applicable to the parties, Gurmej Singh being a collateral of Harnam Singh in the 8th degree could be validly adopted.

anchor.surface_text: The main question which falls to be considered is whether under the terms of the Riwaj-i-am applicable to the parties, Gurmej Singh being a collateral of Harnam Singh in the 8th degree could be validly adopted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Custom directory and ambiguous; factum valet applies; precedents show even peremptory language directory in Punjab customs.

holdings.text: under the Customary Law of Gurdaspur District applicable to the Gill Jats of village Gillanwali, Harnam Singh could only adopt a near collateral and Gurmej Singh being a distant collateral his adoption was invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case was that under the Customary Law of Gurdaspur District applicable to the Gill Jats ,of village Gillanwali, Harnam Singh could only adopt a near collateral and Gurmej Singh being a distant collateral his adoption was invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants' claim rejected as 'near collaterals' undefined and ambiguous; no proof of mandatory limit to third degree.

holdings.text: the custom recorded in the Riwaj-i-am is in derogation of the general custom and those who set up such a custom must prove it by clear and unequivocal language. The language is on the face of it ambiguous [...] the language used amounts to no more than an expression of a wish on the part of the narrators of the custom and is not mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: The expression near collaterals is not defined by the custom. The relevant answer which we have underlined above gives no indication as to the precise import of the words near collaterals. The custom recorded in the Riwaj-i-am is in derogation of the general custom and those who set up such a custom must prove it by clear and unequivocal language.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ambiguous terms; expresses preference/wish; right of selection with adopter; derogation requires strict proof lacking here.

holdings.text: where the texts are merely directory, the principle of factum valet applies, and the act done is valid and binding. [...] We see no reason why a declaration in a Riwaj-i-am should be treated differently and the text of the answer should not be taken to be directory.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to Hindu law directory texts; precedents on Punjab customs despite peremptory language; secular purpose supports directory nature.

holdings.text: under the Customary Law in the Punjab, adoption is secular in character, the object being to appoint an heir and the rules relating to ceremonies and to preferences in selection have to be held to be directory and adoptions made in disregard of them are not invalid.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Basic idea is secular heir appointment for agriculture/family; great latitude unlike religious Hindu adoption; supported by Rattigan and precedents.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, under the Customary Law in the Punjab, adoption is secular in character, the object being to appoint an heir and the rules relating to ceremonies and to preferences in selection have to be held to be directory and adoptions made in disregard of them are number invalid.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; factum and validity of adoption of Gurmej Singh by Harnam Singh upheld under customary law of Gurdaspur District as the rule preferring near collaterals held directory not mandatory

edges.explanation: Petitioner's argument limiting adoptions to near collaterals rebuts the holding allowing distant collateral adoption.

The argument states that Punjab customary adoption allows great latitude in selection of kinsman regardless of degree, directly supporting the holding that an 8th degree collateral could be validly adopted.
The argument on latitude regardless of degree in Punjab customary adoption addresses the issue of whether an 8th degree collateral could be validly adopted under the Riwaj-i-am.

anchor.surface_text: As adopted son he made him the owner of all of his property. We are satisfied that there is ample evidence to sustain the finding on the factum of adoption.

On the other hand, under the Customary Law in the Punjab, adoption is secular in character, the object being to appoint an heir and the rules relating to ceremonies and to preferences in selection have to be held to be directory and adoptions made in disregard of them are number invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The main question which falls to be considered is whether under the terms of the Riwaj-i-am applicable to the parties, Gurmej Singh being a collateral of Harnam Singh in the 8th degree could be validly adopted.

On the other hand, under the Customary Law in the Punjab, adoption is secular in character, the object being to appoint an heir and the rules relating to ceremonies and to preferences in selection have to be held to be directory and adoptions made in disregard of them are number invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case was that under the Customary Law of Gurdaspur District applicable to the Gill Jats ,of village Gillanwali, Harnam Singh could only adopt a near collateral and Gurmej Singh being a distant collateral his adoption was invalid.

On the other hand, under the Customary Law in the Punjab, adoption is secular in character, the object being to appoint an heir and the rules relating to ceremonies and to preferences in selection have to be held to be directory and adoptions made in disregard of them are number invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The expression near collaterals is not defined by the custom. The relevant answer which we have underlined above gives no indication as to the precise import of the words near collaterals. The custom recorded in the Riwaj-i-am is in derogation of the general custom and those who set up such a custom must prove it by clear and unequivocal language.

On the other hand, under the Customary Law in the Punjab, adoption is secular in character, the object being to appoint an heir and the rules relating to ceremonies and to preferences in selection have to be held to be directory and adoptions made in disregard of them are number invalid.

edges.explanation: The holding affirms and applies the factum valet principle to directory Riwaj-i-am declarations.
h5 holding that factum valet applies to directory texts including Riwaj-i-am directly addresses i5 on application to directory declarations
